The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. The most promising approach is to reconstruct quantum theory from a set of axioms. The most ambitious reconstruction programs have been based on the assumption that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functions between them. We provide a set of purely categorical axioms that guarantee this equivalence.

The Myxozoa are a diverse group of microscopic parasites that parasitize both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan was reduced to a minimal structure, and that the genome was reduced in size and gene content. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides a unique resource for understanding the evolution of the Myxozoa. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host immune responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to cause disease. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated factors (ISFs) in order to impair transcriptional induction of ISGs. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 evades the host immune response and may help in the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the Hv1 channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels

The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the global food demand is expected to increase by 50% by 2030. This study quantifies the impact of climate change on maize production and yields, and the impact of this on global food security. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa from DNA sequences. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of diet composition in understanding the role of LMH in African savanna biodiversity. (Read more)

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months, which may lead to permanent closures. These findings have implications for policymakers seeking to support small businesses during the crisis and beyond.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. However, the fate of this missing plastic is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. Our results suggest that the missing plastic debris is mostly removed from the surface of the open ocean by a size-selective sink. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. This sink may be of importance to understand the global load of floating plastic debris. (Less)

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important unsolved problems in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the origin of the universe. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of <300 Ma and >1 Ga, which is consistent with theoretical estimates for the age of the solar system. The grains with ages of <300 Ma condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains with ages >1 Ga were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This study provides a new constraint for the origin of the solar system. (Show more)

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The expansion of the motorized fleet is expected to continue in developing countries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources. Our results highlight the need for more effective management of the global fishing fleet.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also one of the most variable. We show that the reproductive output of mammals is strongly correlated with the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy is not only limited by the amount of resources available in the environment but also by the metabolic power of the mother.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. VX-765 also preserves tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of the mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA by limiting the accumulation of α-syn aggregates. This study opens the way for further preclinical and clinical studies. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling blood pressure, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected to each other in a network. The network is responsible for integrating information from multiple sources and coordinating the activities of the cells. The network is also responsible for the rapid transmission of information throughout the endothelium. This paper describes the nature of the network and its properties. The network is found to be highly efficient in transmitting information throughout the endothelium. The network is also found to be highly dynamic and adaptable. These properties are important for the function of the endothelium and for the health of the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the pandemic and for informing public health policy. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic and for research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is a valuable resource for researchers and policy makers, and we hope that it will be useful to others.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the targets of a large number of drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The activation gate is the main gate of the channel and is responsible for the opening of the channel. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. We have identified a key residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is crucial for the selectivity filter to be conductive or not, and for the activation gate to be open or not. This work provides a structural basis for the understanding of the selectivity filter gating in potassium channels. It also provides a structural basis for the understanding of the selectivity filter gating in potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in human health is still being elucidated, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host and the host environment. The gut microbiome is also influenced by the host diet, and the composition of the microbiome can be used as a biomarker for diet. The gut microbiome is also important for the health of herbivores, such as livestock, and the composition of the microbiome can be used to assess the health of the animal. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome of herbivores, synthesize a variety of natural products that could be used as a source of therapeutics. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are important producers of natural products that could be used for a variety of applications.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior and is often associated with anxiety. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as increased oxidative stress in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with anxiety. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors under large deformation is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general framework for the design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors under large deformation. The hemoglobin (Hb) system is a critical component of human physiology, and its regulation is of great interest. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of human Hb expression. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. We show that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of Hb expression in erythroid cells, and its down-regulation in the adult is associated with a reversal of the Hb expression pattern. This mechanism may be important for the development of Hb expression in humans.

In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) function, highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the long-term use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate the STIM/ORAI Ca2+ signaling pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is a key regulator of vascular remodeling. Our findings may help to explain the adverse effects of LCCBs and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of hypertension.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way federal forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral bird populations, but the opposite occurred for older-forest–associated species. This is partly because of the loss of older forests to fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. The NWFP has been successful in halting the decline of early-seral ecosystems, but the policy has not yet been effective in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. This underscores the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our findings also highlight the importance of monitoring and adaptive management in policy development. (Show more)

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We show that the approach is successful in identifying a compound that is 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The approach is also successful in identifying a compound that is synergistic with colistin, a membrane-weakening drug, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The approach is thus a promising tool for the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of electronic devices before bedtime can have a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices before bedtime can phase-delay the circadian clock, suppress melatonin, and reduce alertness the next morning. These effects are likely to be important for health and safety, as well as for the performance of daily activities.

In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of bulk samples and magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio is consistent with a terrestrial origin. In contrast, the Os isotope composition of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggests mixing with extraterrestrial Os. The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still to be determined. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be exacerbated by other stimuli. This is in contrast to congenital deficiency, which is lethal. The different outcomes are likely due to the different timing of the loss of CTLA-4.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling specialized plant feeding. Our analyses resolved controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, corresponding diversification rate increases suggest that these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that these novel genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant-digesting enzymes. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a sharp boundary. The inner core is a unique part of the Earth that is not well understood. The inner core is believed to have formed by crystallization of the core material. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is more likely to be a two-step process, instead of direct nucleation of the stable, hexagonal close-packed phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana abuse is a major public health problem, and legalization of marijuana is being considered in many countries. However, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are unknown. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This blunted reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might be a key mechanism underlying the addictive and maladaptive behaviors associated with marijuana abuse.

Language is the defining feature of modern humans, and the brain’s processing of language is central to our cognition and behavior. However, the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful deep learning models in language processing achieve state-of-the-art performance on a key language comprehension task by predicting nearly 100% of neural activity in the brain. These models also generalize across datasets and imaging modalities. We discuss the implications of these results for the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms. Our results provide computationally explicit evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms are fundamentally predictive in nature. This view is consistent with the brain’s predictive coding framework and may have implications for the brain’s other cognitive and sensory functions. (Show more)

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that many deep learning algorithms are unstable in the limit. We also show that this instability is not inherent to deep learning, but rather is a consequence of the fact that the algorithms are not general purpose. This work is a step toward understanding the limits of deep learning and the development of general purpose algorithms for scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past epidemics. This article discusses a classic experiment that has been cited as evidence for such a failure. The experiment’s design flaws were not noticed at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of how people fail to understand exponential growth. In hindsight, this is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the identification of the causative agent has been a long and difficult process. We sequenced the genome of a patient with leprosy and found that it is very similar to that of a leprosy-associated reactional state, known as Lucio's phenomenon. This finding suggests that the two conditions are caused by the same organism, which has been named Mycobacterium lepromatosis. The genome sequence also reveals that the two leprosy bacilli have diverged little since their separation from a common ancestor approximately 14 million years ago. This finding has implications for understanding the evolution of the leprosy disease complex and the origin of the disease. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related, as revealed by the study of quantum quenches. However, the entanglement dynamics is a highly nontrivial problem, which has been studied so far only for noninteracting systems. We show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is a natural regime for the study of entanglement. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions, which are both well established in the interacting case. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our work opens the door to the study of entanglement in interacting systems. It also provides a powerful tool for the study of entanglement in general many-body systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors, which are associated with safety concerns. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but robustly grows at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is also protective in hamsters, a relevant animal model for COVID-19. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. The vaccine is a promising candidate for the global fight against COVID-19. (Show more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with multiple transmission pathways. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe and may help to prevent future outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is rarely studied. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. We also show that relative brain size is associated with relative neuronal cell density in reptiles, birds, and primates but not in other mammals. This suggests that the evolution of neuronal density may be a more reliable indicator of brain power than brain size.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This is the first study to show that TRAP1 can regulate the metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in mammalian cells. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, how it does so is not well understood. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose ingestion relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that is responsible for translating messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences into proteins. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a long-standing and controversial topic. We use a quantitative approach to test hypotheses for the drivers of body size evolution in aquatic mammals. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. The optimum size occurs at an intermediate value where thermoregulatory costs are low but feeding efficiency remains high. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. This work provides a quantitative framework for understanding the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals. (Show more)

The type IV pili of bacteria are major surface adhesins that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses type IV pili as a sensor to detect the mechanical activity of the pili, which is required for surface sensing. The pili-mediated surface sensing system is a unique example of a mechanosensitive signaling pathway that regulates the activity of pili. This finding provides a new perspective on the physiological roles of type IV pili and opens up new avenues for understanding the evolution of bacterial pili. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the impact of pesticides on aquatic ecosystems is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the global pesticide situation and is a first step toward a better understanding of the impact of pesticides on aquatic ecosystems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology and evolution of emerging viruses. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe disease and can act as a reservoir for other viruses. Our findings suggest that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer and that multiple human-to-deer transmission events have occurred. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the lives of millions of people. This paper examines the causes of this problem, the impacts of dams, and the solutions that are needed. We show that the problems are not only caused by the hydropower industry but also by governments, international organizations, and civil society. We also show that the solutions are not only possible but also necessary to ensure that hydropower can continue to be a renewable source of energy that is needed to meet the world’s energy demands.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by chronic inflammation. However, the origin of this inflammatory response is still debated. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric forms of amyloid-β (Aβ) are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain. We demonstrate that neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors, even in the absence of extracellular plaques and cell death. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis. Our findings provide a novel perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest known site where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the cell and are regulated by multiple gates. The K+ channel BK channel is a unique channel in that it does not possess an intracellular activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that C-type inactivation in BK channels is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to involve the construction of a nested tree structure, in which words are embedded in phrases, which are embedded in clauses, and so on. However, there is no direct evidence for this assumption. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This work provides a new perspective on the nature of language processing and opens up new avenues for future research.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the LH. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity, a major health problem in the United States and worldwide.

However, the use of free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria as biofertilizers is limited by the lack of a sustainable way to control the activity of the symbiosis. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. Our results are consistent with the idea that the presence of external authorities can increase the effectiveness of local monitoring. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for outbreaks that have affected millions of people. The fate of carbon (C) in agricultural soils is critical for mitigating climate change. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of the type of pollinator attracted to the plant. We demonstrate that nesocodin is attractive to the vertebrate pollinator, Phelsuma geckos, and provide evidence for convergent evolution of this trait in two other hummingbird-visited species. Our findings suggest that the color of nectar is a trait that is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 490 and 620 AD. Our data show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that women with skull deformations had a genetic ancestry that is not consistent with modern Europeans. Finally, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical for early detection and response to emerging and reemerging pathogens. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in Cambodia. We identified chikungunya virus as the first pathogen detected in a patient with undifferentiated fever, which was followed by a large national outbreak. We also identified Plasmodium knowlesi, a zoonotic pathogen that is often overlooked in the clinical setting. Our study demonstrates the utility of metagenomic sequencing in resource-limited settings and the potential for early detection of emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. (Show more)

The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, the replication of genetic information was accomplished by RNA molecules. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA molecules from an RNA template. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world and the origin of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 were identified. The results showed that the immune system was suppressed, and the inflammatory monocytes and pathogenic T cells were increased. Tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can effectively improve the clinical symptoms and reduce mortality. The results provide a new idea for the treatment of severe COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of these mechanisms in the maintenance of copper homeostasis and in interactions with competing microbes is not. Here we demonstrate that the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic cluster in other fungi is not a coincidence, but rather a mechanism for the maintenance of copper homeostasis and for interactions with competing microbes. This work provides a new perspective on the role of fungal natural products in the maintenance of essential micronutrients and in interactions with competing microbes. (Read more)

The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the bulk composition is consistent with a “Lake Gale” catchment environment. The amorphous silica is precipitated from variable aqueous solutions, and the mixed-cation salts and oxides are precipitates and/or their diagenesis products. The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery, and the detection of tridymite in a martian drill sample is a first for the study of the Moon, Mercury, and other planetary bodies. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture worldwide. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are adapted to the geographic distribution of frost damage. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt land management and forestry practices to the changing frost risk. Our results can also help to improve the accuracy of crop and forest insurance policies. Finally, our findings can help to improve our understanding of the evolutionary impact of frost events on plant and animal populations.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may be important for the initiation and maintenance of colitis. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different causes and different stages of disease at death. We report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This method will be useful for studying the disease and developing therapeutics. The method is also applicable to other diseases, such as Huntington’s disease, and can be adapted to other species. This method will be useful for studying the disease and developing therapeutics. The ability of pathogens to influence the microbiota of their vectors is a key factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of the vector tick Ixodes scapularis to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that the bacterium induces ticks to produce antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota. Mechanistically, the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short tail of modern birds is thought to have evolved from a long tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle) in the basal birds. However, the diversity of early pygostylians is limited, and the origin of the short tail is poorly understood. Here, we describe a basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. Our study increases the known diversity of early pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of the avian tail. We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. This work is an important step toward understanding the role of stratospheric water vapor in the climate system. It also provides a benchmark for future studies. (Show more)

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and even yellow, orange, and white. These colors are determined by the absorption and scattering properties of the pigments that are present in the animal. However, some vertebrates have distinctive colors, such as blue-green bones and other tissues. This phenomenon is called chlorosis, and it is present in many species. Here, we show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans (frogs and toads), and that it is associated with the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is present in the blood. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for chlorosis, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study also presents evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis in anurans. Finally, we show that the presence of chlorosis is associated with the ability to absorb light in the near-infrared range, which is important for camouflage in green foliage. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The identification of factors that promote the development of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) is important for the development of new therapies. We report that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the percentage of BCSCs. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α pathways. ALKBH5 expression is required for the enrichment of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. This study provides a mechanism for the development of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. (Show more)

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment from the earliest pocket Bibles. (Less)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of extinction and recovery. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 My, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the recovery was protracted. These results are critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily and plays important roles in various biological processes, such as metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. However, the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific role of RORα remains unclear. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the spike protein at 3.0-Å resolution and show that the D614G mutation has led to a range of more open conformations. These conformational changes may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2, and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. These results provide a basis for understanding the impact of the D614G mutation on the infectivity of the virus. They also provide a basis for understanding the impact of other mutations on the infectivity of the virus. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir [J. Econ. Theory 110, 1–21 (2003)] to the case of Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is also a step toward the study of repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. Our projections highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that have led to the disproportionate burden of COVID-19 on racial and ethnic minorities.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and physics. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be modified under pressure, and we propose a pressure-dependent electronegativity and chemical hardness scale. This scale can be used to predict and explain many exotic chemical phenomena under pressure. This work provides a new perspective on the chemical properties of atoms and opens up new avenues for the study of chemical phenomena under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the impact of fire on climate change is not well understood because of the complexity of the fire–climate–carbon cycle system. We show that changes in human demography can have a large impact on fire activity, which in turn can have a large impact on climate change. Our results suggest that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks, as caused by changing fire regimes, are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our results have implications for the design of climate mitigation policies. Our model is available for download.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, at a specific time of day. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-dependent regulation of symbiont numbers and luminescence is also present in other hosts, suggesting that it may be a general mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in host–microbe interactions. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a generative model to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent discourse atoms. We can infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This approach can be extended to other domains and applications. We believe that this method will be useful to many researchers. We hope that it will be widely adopted.

The second plague pandemic, which started in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents. Our study shows that the introduction of Y. pestis into Europe was preceded by repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia. This finding challenges the traditional view of plague as a disease that established itself in Europe without any human-mediated introductions. Our results suggest that the introduction of plague into Europe was a complex process, involving multiple introductions and a long period of adaptation. This study provides evidence for the importance of climate in the introduction of plague into Europe. (Less)

The sea star wasting syndrome (SSWS) is a disease outbreak affecting a large number of asteroid species on the Pacific Coast. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the animal. We show that the disease is caused by a virus. The virus is transmitted by starfish and is present in the plankton and sediments. The virus has been present on the Pacific Coast for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of new targets for therapy is of great importance. Here we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is a promising target for therapy of AML. We show that IL1RAP is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in a substantial proportion of AML patients and that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that the antibody can be used to treat primary AML cells in vitro and in vivo. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also provide a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment for AML. This approach could be extended to other targets of interest. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The settlement history of Madagascar is still debated, and we used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island. We find that Madagascar is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The settlement history of Madagascar is recent, but the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement happened independently from Africa and Asia. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar and its impact on the present genomic diversity. It also provides a reference for future studies on the human population of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases its activity. We show that the RNA also regulates expression of two other genes. The RNA and protein are important for growth on glycerol and galactose, two carbon sources that are important in biotechnology. The RNA and protein are also important for growth in the presence of ethanol, a carbon source that is important in the food industry. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the durability of the current vaccines and the need for new therapeutics. Here, we demonstrate the utility of a deep learning algorithm in antibody engineering to improve the neutralizing activity of an approved antibody. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to address the current challenges in the development of therapeutics against SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work also demonstrates the potential of deep learning in the design of other protein molecules, such as enzymes and proteins involved in the immune system. This approach can be extended to other protein molecules and may help to address the challenges in the development of therapeutics in the future.

Crop expert surveys are a rich source of information on crop status, but are rarely used in agricultural applications. We show how to convert the original categorical data into a continuous probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that the resulting crop condition index is more accurate than official forecasts released midseason. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert surveys in agricultural applications, and can be extended to other applications such as livestock, forestry, and fisheries. Our framework can also be used to assess the accuracy of other crop monitoring systems, and to identify biases in the data. Finally, our framework can be extended to other applications such as livestock, forestry, and fisheries.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the order of presentation of words in a sentence. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the order of presentation of words in a sentence. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it is marked by a lack of fossil evidence. Here, we present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings have implications for the study of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes and the origin of parasitic lifestyles. They also provide a model for the study of the molecular evolution of genomes under progressively relaxed functional constraints. This model can be applied to other genomes and to other evolutionary transitions. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was a stark reminder of the vulnerability of South Africa and other water-scarce regions to extreme droughts. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 80% by the year 2100 under a high-emission scenario. This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results also show that the probability of a multiyear rainfall deficit in SSA is higher than previously thought. This is important for the design of drought risk management strategies. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been a major advance in materials science. The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, is a unique event in the history of science. The discovery of anthropogenic quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion provides a unique opportunity to study the conditions under which quasicrystals form and to study the history of the Earth.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of chlorophyll, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in multiple sclerosis (MS) and other neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. However, the precise roles of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. Here, we show that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. ASK1-deficient microglia/macrophages were sufficient to induce astrocyte activation, which subsequently exacerbated neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the roles of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MS and other neurodegenerative diseases. The 2012–2014 California drought is the driest period in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to anthropogenic warming. Our results suggest that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions will continue to increase in the future, and that the risk of drought will continue to increase. This conclusion is important for California and other regions that are warming and drying.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the converging functions of autism-risk genes and may facilitate the identification of causal paths. This study also provides a model system for studying the role of behavioral flexibility in autism. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive news content, and that this negativity bias is present across cultures and continents. However, individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is also evident, and this variation is likely to be important for understanding the news media’s role in shaping public opinion. The results also suggest that, if the news media are seeking out and reporting more negative content, this may be having a significant impact on public opinion around the world. Finally, the results highlight the importance of considering individual-level variation in the study of news media effects.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in its pore-forming protein and Ca2+ sensor result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel, which result in hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also highlights the importance of functional characterization of mutations in the context of a disease-causing protein. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in Drosophila is a result of both active release and endocytic uptake. We demonstrate that the spread of aggregates is a noncell-autonomous process, and that the loss of vulnerable neurons can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis in these neurons. Finally, we show that the spread of aggregates requires active release and uptake, and that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may help to identify potential therapeutic targets.
