The role of bats as reservoirs of zoonotic viruses is increasingly recognized, but the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats to other animals and humans are poorly understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated its immunosuppressant activity. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The immunosuppressant protein identified in this study may be a potential target for the prevention and treatment of viral spillover from bats to other animals and humans. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses. (Show more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. One-carbon units are critical for cell growth, and SHMT is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in mice blocks tumor growth. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, and show that they block cancer cell growth in vitro and in vivo. Finally, we show that formate, the one-carbon donor, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These results provide a rationale for the clinical development of SHMT inhibitors in cancer. They also suggest that formate-based inhibitors may be a useful platform for the development of cancer therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous motor neuron disease with a variety of neuropathological subtypes. The presence of inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS suggests that the disease is associated with the formation of proteins that are supersaturated. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners of these proteins. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a rationale for the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS. It also suggests that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS is a general feature of the disease. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the origin of the aquatic flowering plants is even less understood. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. The study of more than 1,000 specimens of Montsechia reveals that it is an aquatic flowering plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and that it is sister to Ceratophyllum. This opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the early diversification of some early flowering plants. The study of Montsechia also raises questions about the timing of the origin of the flowering plants. The age of Montsechia is Barremian, which is younger than the age of the origin of the flowering plants in many cladistic analyses. The age of Montsechia also raises questions about the timing of the origin of the flowering plants in the context of the Cretaceous greenhouse effect. The study of Montsechia and its implications for the origin of the flowering plants is presented here. (Less)

The evolution of viruses is often studied using sequences from modern viruses. However, the evolutionary history of viruses is likely to be shaped by the evolutionary history of the host. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the human pathogen B19V has been part of the human evolutionary history for a long time. We also show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that the evolutionary history of viruses is likely to be shaped by the evolutionary history of the host. This is important for understanding the evolution of viruses in general. The rate of sea level rise is one of the most visible and controversial aspects of climate change. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is the longest time series available. The results are consistent with the IPCC AR5 model projections. The study also provides a new estimate of the acceleration of global mean sea level, which is important for understanding the causes of sea level rise.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the nature and causes of the pain epidemic are unclear. We show that, in America today, pain is less common in the elderly than in midlife. This is a mystery, given the expectation that pain will increase with age. We show that the erosion of working-class life is a likely explanation.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. The atomic-level characterization of enzyme active sites by NMR-assisted crystallography offers a powerful approach to understanding the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates. Here, this approach is used to study the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The results provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of this intermediate, including the location of the water molecule that serves as a hydrogen bond donor to the ε-amino group of the catalytic βLys87. The results also highlight the importance of the active site environment for the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. These results are expected to be broadly applicable to other β-elimination and replacement reactions. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate emphasizes the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, was shown to inhibit SARS-CoV replication in vitro and in vivo. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection prevented disease, reduced virus replication, and decreased lung lesions. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial setting, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of a rapid response to emerging viruses. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, at a specific time of day. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-catabolizing activity is also required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic crypts, which is essential for the luminescence of the symbionts. We propose that this strategy is used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis by the provision of nutrients. (Show more)

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcription. We found that the transcription machinery can recognize and bypass alkylated DNA lesions. We also found that the transcription machinery can recognize and bypass alkylated DNA lesions. We also found that the transcription machinery can recognize and bypass alkylated DNA lesions. The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Virions must first be secreted from virus-producing cells, and then bind to target-cell receptors, before sequential proteolysis occurs. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, precleaved MERS viruses used receptor-proximal, cell-surface proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry, whereas the more rigid uncleaved MERS viruses trafficked past these cell-surface proteases and into endosomes. The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of global disease burden. The food choices people make are a key driver of these trends. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large catering operation can have a significant impact on meal selection. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in a wide range of settings. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available could lead to proportional reductions in meat consumption of 60% or more. This is a significant contribution to the global effort to reduce the environmental and health impacts of the food system. The results also suggest that the impact of this intervention is concentrated among the people who are least likely to select vegetarian meals today. This suggests that the intervention could be used to target the people who are most in need of dietary change. The results also suggest that the intervention may be effective in other settings, such as hospitals. This study provides a model for how interventions can be used to promote sustainable diets at the population level.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward understanding the role of the cell surface proteome in cancer biology and drug discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge of interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings also suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with little to no adverse effects on electoral outcomes. This is an important contribution to the literature on the effects of election administration policies.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid understanding of the virus and its interactions with the host. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a. This structure provides a foundation for understanding the function of ORF8 in the context of the virus and its interactions with the host.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition, and knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and that this effect is mediated by the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF)/CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) pathway. We also show that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of endothelin-1 (ET-1) expression. Finally, using transfected cells, we show that transfected CRFR1 contributes to edema via transfected AQP4. In conclusion, hypobaric hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and edema. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies. The problem of selective inference is that having cherry-picked a dataset, we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This is a challenge in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We also discuss the implications of selective inference for the interpretation of results from complex statistical models. We conclude with a discussion of the challenges and opportunities for future research.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step for the regeneration of organs, such as the liver. However, the generation of vascular networks is a challenging task because of the complexity of the vascular system. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can induce the formation of vascular networks in the liver. Our study provides a promising approach for the regeneration of organs. (Show more)

The discovery of the ligand for the orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened a new field of research in the biology of RTKs. In this study, we show that the zebrafish genome encodes three ligands for Alk and Ltk. We demonstrate that these ligands play an important role in pigment development and that they are essential for the formation of iridophores, the pigment-producing cells of the eye and the tail. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a model system for the study of ligand-activated RTKs and their physiological functions. (Show more)

The role of STING in β-cell function and insulin secretion is unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. STING deficiency also led to down-regulation of Pax6 protein and nuclear localization. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings also provide a rationale for the development of STING-targeted therapies for the treatment of type 2 diabetes. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is a unique feature among viruses. This genome organization offers evolutionary advantages, but it also complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction we identified is a key step in the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. The lack of conservation of this interaction among influenza A viruses might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of the influenza A virus life cycle. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, the frequency and severity of wildfire in the United States has increased substantially in recent decades, and is projected to continue to increase in the future. In this paper, we show that human activities have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that human-caused wildfires are disproportionally occurring in areas where people live and work. These findings highlight the importance of reducing wildfire risk to people and ecosystems, and provide a rationale for reducing human-caused wildfire ignitions.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical processes that shape urban change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune response is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid growth of the virus, the short eclipse phase, and the rapid clearance of the virus. We also show that the model can be used to assess the effect of antiviral treatment on the disease outcome. Our results can help in the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying processes are poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky and allows the dissemination of cancer cells. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can also affect the composition of the microbiome and, in turn, the tumorigenicity of the epithelium. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our experiments highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer progression and for developing strategies to control tumorigenesis. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Although the majority of breast cancers are hormone receptor-positive, a small proportion are triple-negative, and these are more likely to be aggressive. Chemotherapy is the main treatment for breast cancer, but the response to this treatment is unpredictable. Here we show that targeting the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer.

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is controversial. We show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a unique, ∼192-y series of volcanic eruptions, which plausibly led to stratospheric ozone depletion and changes in Southern Hemisphere circulation and climate. This finding provides a new perspective on the timing of the start of deglaciation and the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the past. It also suggests that the start of deglaciation may have been triggered by volcanic eruptions, which may have important implications for the future. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that inland fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. Our findings underscore the importance of freshwater ecosystems for both human well-being and biodiversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve a high capacity and a low operating potential range. Furthermore, a hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate after injury, a phenomenon that is thought to be due to the absence of a MAPK signaling pathway. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of this pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is enhanced by activating calcium signaling. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration is a powerful platform for discovery of genes involved in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate is not a fixed property of the nervous system but rather is dependent on the developmental history of the neuron. These findings have implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genomic stability. In many organisms, hotspots of recombination are known to occur in promoter regions of genes. However, the distribution of recombination across the genome is highly variable, and it is unclear whether hotspots are distributed randomly or are organized in some way. We use a population genomic approach to study recombination in a flowering plant, and we find that hotspots are distributed in a highly organized way, with some regions of the genome exhibiting no recombination at all. This study provides a detailed view of the organization of recombination across the genome.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of networks of functionally related regions, which are hypothesized to reflect the organization of the brain in health and disease. However, the number of networks is still limited, and the functional significance of the networks is not fully understood. Here, we show that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the DMN, but that this RSN is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. Furthermore, we show that the dominant metabolic RSN is reduced in cognitive impairment in Alzheimer’s disease. These results provide a direct link between the metabolic organization of the brain and its functional organization. This approach can be used to identify the functional significance of the networks and to assess the impact of disease on the brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. We show that a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap, is also present on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. The discovery of the NAD+ cap in eukaryotes raises the possibility that this modification could be important in regulating gene expression. The identification of the NAD+ cap in yeast opens the door to the study of the function of this modification in eukaryotes.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control can prevent the progression of microvascular complications in people with type 1 and type 2 diabetes. However, the long-term effects of intensive therapy on the progression of macrovascular complications are less clear. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood mononuclear cells persist for several years during the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study, a long-term follow-up of the DCCT. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia and may contribute to the metabolic memory of intensive therapy. These results support an epigenetic explanation for the long-term effects of intensive therapy on macrovascular complications. They also suggest that epigenetic modifications may be a target for therapeutic interventions to prevent or treat diabetic complications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. The etiology of this disorder is still poorly understood, but it is believed to be multifactorial. In this study, we show that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disorder. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and may be a target in the management of this disorder. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. Among these volatiles are several aromatic and aliphatic nitrogen-containing compounds for which the biosynthetic pathways are not known. Using an introgression population derived from the green-fruited species Solanum pennellii, we identified a locus essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. Silencing of the underlying gene in transgenic plants abolished production of aliphatic and aromatic nitrogenous volatiles in ripe fruit, and metabolomic analysis of these fruit revealed the accumulation of 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid, a known conjugate of cysteine and 3-methylbutanal. This pathway is a major step forward in understanding and ultimately improving tomato flavor quality. (Read more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We demonstrate that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species, which in turn affect the contribution of diversity to ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for understanding the impacts of anthropogenic climate change on the functioning of Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to reflect different aspects of space. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the spatial layout of the environment, are anatomically distinct from other cell types and exhibit strong coupling among themselves. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC cell types and will be useful for understanding the function of MEC in navigation. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. This study provides a unique example of flowering regulation in plants and may help to understand the evolution of flowering in plants.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The pathophysiology of the disease is not fully understood, but it is clear that it is associated with the loss of dopamine-containing neurons. Here, we show that the dopamine system is much more complex than previously thought and that it is also affected in disease. We identify a previously unrecognized system within the dopamine-containing nigral system that is likely to be affected in Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. This system, termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” is formed by striosomes, dopamine-containing dendrites, and other cell types. The bouquets are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease. This work provides a new perspective on the dopamine system and its role in the brain.

We know that people feel connected when they are talking to each other. But how do we know when two people are feeling connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for regulating heart rate. SAN cells are specialized cardiomyocytes that are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. SAN cells are also responsible for maintaining the rhythm of the heart by integrating signals from the heart’s internal Ca2+ store and the plasma membrane. We show that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ signaling in SAN cells and is essential for maintaining the rhythmicity of the SAN. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the heart and provide a molecular mechanism for how Ca2+ signaling in SAN cells is regulated. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact synergistically to promote plant resistance against insect herbivores. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the beneficial effects of Si on plant resistance against insect herbivores and may lead to the development of Si-based pest management strategies in agriculture. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin biosynthesis is important for the lipidome of murine macrophages and that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages. Furthermore, we show that tetrahydrobiopterin biosynthesis is important for the function of macrophages. These findings have implications for the understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and for the function of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the order of presentation of information. This makes it suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time within dynamic memory registers. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the internalization and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. The impact of nutrient loading on coastal ecosystems is often attributed to large rivers and estuaries, but this study shows that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas. Although they represent only a modest proportion of lake-wide loads, expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. Our findings also highlight the importance of considering the spatial heterogeneity of nutrient sources in large water bodies, which can be driven by local conditions such as land cover and dams. This study provides a snapshot of nutrient inputs from all tributaries of a large lake, which can be used to inform future research and management efforts. Our findings have implications for the management of coastal ecosystems worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is coupled to an environment that makes strong thermodynamic forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems theory. Our results suggest that the saddle-node bifurcation may be a general feature of complex chemical networks that are coupled to environments that make strong forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. This finding may have important implications for the design of synthetic chemical networks that are intended to operate in environments that are difficult to access. (Show more)

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We use a combination of in vitro and in vivo experiments to show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex, which can then predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. This work offers mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. These findings may help to explain the diverse range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs and may also help to identify patients who are likely to benefit from immunotherapy. This work also highlights the importance of understanding the effects of antibodies on the microcircuitry of the brain. This is a major step forward in our understanding of the mechanisms of autoimmune encephalitis. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and it is important to understand the history of abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the warming was accompanied by a global-scale perturbation of the carbon cycle, which was linked to an increase in atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. These findings provide insights into the potential for future abrupt warming events and the potential for the carbon cycle to play a role in such events. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and certification is the most common tool used to meet corporate sustainability commitments. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has been unclear. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis. It is conserved from bacteria to humans. The exocyst complex is involved in several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In species with a single locus, sex is determined by a single genotype, and the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype of the gonads. In species with multiple alleles at a sex locus, sex is determined by the genotype of the gonads and sex can be male, female, or intersex. Here we show that the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii has a sex determination locus with multiple alleles, and that the alleles interact to produce four possible genotypes, which can be male or female. We discuss the evolutionary consequences of this modular sex determination system. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of lipofuscin, a yellow pigment that is a mixture of oxidized and degraded retinaldehyde-based compounds. These compounds are photooxidized and degraded into reactive intermediates that can cause damage to the retina. We show that the accumulation of the most abundant of these compounds, A2E, is reduced in mice treated with a chelator of iron, a metal that is known to be elevated in the retina. These findings suggest that the accumulation of lipofuscin is influenced by the levels of iron in the retina. This work also demonstrates that the degradation of A2E is light-dependent and that the presence of iron can accelerate this process. These findings have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and thus understanding how they diversify their diets is a fundamental question in ecology. Predator specialization is often considered an evolutionary dead end, but in some predators, morphological and functional optimizations are localized in separate structures dedicated to prey capture. We show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians, have evolved modular prey capture systems that are linked to the diversification of their diets. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide a case study for understanding the evolution of morphological innovations and the role of modularity in the diversification of predator diets.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. Despite the discovery of relatively complete hands from two early hominin species, the evolution of the hand is poorly understood during the time interval between these discoveries and the emergence of modern human-like hand morphology and function. Here we report the discovery of a hand fossil from a Middle Pleistocene hominin that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also highlights the importance of the fossil record for understanding the evolution of the human hand. (Show more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. One-carbon units are critical for cell growth, and SHMT is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in mice blocks tumor growth. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, and show that they block cancer cell growth in vitro and in vivo. Finally, we show that formate, the one-carbon donor, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These results have implications for cancer therapy and for the design of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT. This study shows that deforestation can have negative impacts on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This is an important finding given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The study also highlights the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, and the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in strategies to improve food and nutrition security. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the impacts of deforestation on people’s diets.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for the expansion of arable land and the production of more food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the paradox of prehistoric subsoil compaction, with potential loss of productivity, is a result of the roaming of sauropods, which may have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. This hypothesis suggests that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the importance of considering the mechanical properties of the soil when designing farm machinery. (Show more)
